Award.AwardTitle: The GRIK-SnRK1 Protein Kinase Cascade And Its Potential Role In Regulating TCP Transcription Factors In Arabidopsis

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: The TCPs constitute a large family of plant-specific transcription factors that are defined by a conserved basic helix-loop-helix domain. They fall into two classes with Class I TCPs promoting cell proliferation, and Class II members promoting leaf and floral differentiation. TCPs are sequence-specific DNA binding proteins that bind to shared or overlapping motifs as homo- or heterodimers. Given the complexity of the TCP family and its potential to function combinatorially, it is likely to be governed by an intricate array of regulatory mechanisms. The overall goal of the project is to examine the role of the GRIK-SnRK1 protein kinase cascade in TCP regulation. Although SnRK1 is best known for controlling and coordinating carbon metabolism and energy balance in plants, there is increasing evidence that it also plays an essential role in plant development and controls plant gene expression by phosphorylating transcription factors. GRIK, which activates SnRK1, only accumulates in young plant tissues, cultured cells and geminivirus-infected cells, all of which replicate plant chromosomal DNA. A subset of Arabidopsis TCPs are phosphorylated by the GRIK-SnRK1 kinase cascade, and Class I TCP binding motifs are enriched in SnRK1-down regulated genes. The project will characterize GRIK-SnRK1 target residues of selected TCPs and examine the consequence of altering their phosphorylation status on TCP function. This research represents an important first step in understanding how TCPs are regulated by phosphorylation and the role of post-translational mechanisms in modulating this unique transcription factor family in plants. A better understanding of TCP regulatory mechanisms and the role of the GRIK-SnRK1 cascade in TCP control could lead to the development of new strategies for modulating plant growth, especially under metabolic stress conditions.

Broader Impacts: The combined application of molecular, cellular and biochemical techniques to TCP phosphorylation provides a unique training opportunity for undergraduate, graduate and senior researchers. The PIs will work together to foster intellectual and collaborative interactions between their laboratories to ensure that participants are broadly trained and develop the skills necessary to apply integrated approaches to complex biological problems. Project participants will also work with local educators and the NC Museum of Life and Science to offer a two-day workshop based on a genetic "Science in a Suitcase" kit for middle school teachers. The kit is designed as a supplemental teaching aid for teachers embarking on genetics content in the middle school grades and is aligned to the NC Standard Course of Study to ensure maximum potential use. Workshop topics will include kit contents, the NC Standard Course of Study requirements, classroom implementation, overview of genetic science at the middle grades level, and assessment of learning strategies. The outreach project has the potential to reach 3,600 middle school students in NC Granville and Durham Counties, both of which have large numbers of minority and economically disadvantage students. The broader impacts include engaging 30 middle grades math and science teachers in the workshops, providing follow-up support through the Museum staff, and providing the kit at no-cost to participating teachers during the following academic year.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The TCPs (Teosinte branched 1/Cycloidea/Proliferating cell factors) are an ancient family of plant-specific transcription factors that link cell cycle and growth pathways and play key roles in proliferation and differentiation. Plants encode many TCPs that have a shared DNA binding domain that recognizes a common DNA sequence. As a consequence, DNA binding per se cannot confer specific regulation to different TCP family members. However, TCPs differ significantly from each other outside of their DNA binding domains, and these unique regions could play important roles in regulation. A post-translational modification of an amino acid in a unique region could alter modulate TCP function by altering interactions, subcellular location and/or protein stability.

Many transcription factors are regulated by phosphorylation because of its strong effect on protein function and reversibility. The SnRK1 (SNF1-related) protein kinase is critical for regulation of many plant signalling pathways including global regulation of metabolism and energy conservation. SnRK1 also plays a role in regulation of plant development, most likely by modulating transcription factors to alter gene expression programs. GRIK (Geminivirus Rep Interacting Kinase) phosphorylates and activates SnRK1. This project explored the relationship between the GRIK-SnRK1 protein kinase cascade and TCP regulation in Arabidopsis, which encodes 24 TCPs.

SnRK1 phosphorylated 11 Arabidopsis TCPs in kinase assays using purified SnRK1 and GRIK. Analysis of TCP truncations in kinase assays indicated that SnRK1 does not phosphorylate the TCP domain. Mapping studies showed that SnRK1 specifically phosphorylates TCPs on serine residues located outside of the TCP domains. Interestingly, the contexts of the SnRK1 target sites in the TCPs do not resemble the published SnRK1 consensus, suggesting that there are additional amino acids motifs associated with SnRK1 phosphorylation. Analysis of TCP phosphomutants demonstrated the SnRK1 phosphorylation does not impact DNA binding activity in vitro. However, SnRK1 phosphorylation impaired TCP interactions with BRM, a subunit of the SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complex and reduced TCP binding to selected target genes in Arabidopsis cells. Together, these results support a model in which SnRK1 phosphorylation interferes with TCP association with chromatin  by preventing binding to BRM. They also implicate SnRK1 in the differential regulation of selected TCP family members.

SnRK1 also modulates plant responses to abiotic and biotic stresses, and phosphorylates viral proteins during geminivirus infection. (Geminiviruses are a large family of plant DNA viruses that cause serious disease and crop losses worldwide.) SnRK1 phosphorylates the viral replication protein (Rep) and interferes with binding to the viral origin of replication, which in turn interferes with viral replication and infection. SnRK1 also phosphorylates the viral anti-silencing protein (AL2/C2) and slows down the infection process. The SnRK1 phosphorylation site is highly conserved in Rep protein of geminiviruses around the world, while the AL2/C2 site is only found in New World viruses. Hence, SnRK1-geminivirus interactions are diverse and evolving overtime, indicative of the dynamic nature of plant-virus pathosystems.

Our findings contributed new information about plant transcription and signal transduction and provided a link between the GRIK/SnRK1 protein kinase cascade and TCP transcription factors in plants. Our results also implicated the GRIK-SnRK1 protein kinase cascade in the host defense response against geminiviruses. The project provided insight into the role of the GRIK-SnRK1 protein kinase cascade in the integration of energy balance and nutrient availability with plant development and response to disease.
